title: Fast.ai vs Cursor v2: AI Development Tools Compared (2025)
metaDescription: Fast.ai vs Cursor v2 in 2025: Compare the open-source deep learning framework with the AI-powered code editor. Discover which tool fits your ML development or coding workflow best.
introduction:
In the rapidly evolving landscape of AI development tools for 2025, two distinct platforms stand out for their transformative approaches: Fast.ai and Cursor v2. While both leverage artificial intelligence to empower developers, they target fundamentally different stages of the creation process. Fast.ai is a specialized, high-level library that democratizes deep learning, enabling practitioners to build and deploy sophisticated neural network models for vision, NLP, and tabular data with remarkable simplicity and state-of-the-art results. Its philosophy centers on education and practical application, abstracting away the complexity of PyTorch.

Conversely, Cursor v2 represents the next generation of AI-assisted software development. It's not a framework for building AI models, but an intelligent code editor rebuilt with a local-first, agentic architecture. Its core function is to understand, plan, and autonomously execute complex code changes across an entire codebase, acting as a copilot that can reason about and manipulate software projects. This comparison will dissect these two powerful but orthogonal tools, clarifying their unique value propositions to help you choose the right instrument for your specific task, whether it's crafting machine learning models or writing and refactoring application code.

sections.title: Overview
paragraphs: Fast.ai is a deep learning framework and educational platform built on PyTorch. It provides high-level APIs that simplify the process of training accurate models, emphasizing a 'top-down' learning approach where users achieve practical results quickly. It's designed for data scientists, researchers, and students who want to implement cutting-edge ML techniques like transfer learning with minimal boilerplate code, covering domains like computer vision, natural language processing, and tabular data analysis.

Cursor v2 is a major evolution of the AI-powered code editor, shifting to a local-first architecture with deeply integrated autonomous agents. It transforms the IDE into an active participant in the development process. Instead of just suggesting snippets, Cursor v2 can plan and execute multi-file refactors, understand codebase context through built-in search and reasoning, and work seamlessly within a familiar VS Code-compatible environment. It's built for software engineers and developers looking to accelerate coding, debugging, and large-scale project maintenance.

sections.title: Pricing Comparison
paragraphs: The pricing models highlight the core difference in their offerings. Fast.ai is completely open-source and free to use. There are no tiers, subscriptions, or usage limits. This aligns with its educational mission and lowers the barrier to entry for anyone wanting to learn or apply deep learning. All features, from its high-level APIs to its interpretability tools, are available without cost, though users must provide their own computational resources (e.g., GPUs). Cursor v2 operates on a freemium model. A free tier offers basic AI-assisted editing capabilities, but advanced features—particularly the autonomous agentic workflows, sophisticated codebase reasoning, and team collaboration tools—are gated behind a paid subscription. This model funds the development of complex, compute-intensive AI features that run locally or via connected services.

sections.title: Features & Capabilities
paragraphs: Fast.ai's features are laser-focused on the machine learning pipeline. Its flagship DataBlock API simplifies data loading and augmentation. It includes built-in support for SOTA architectures (ResNet, AWD-LSTM) and makes transfer learning accessible in a few lines of code. Advanced training utilities like the learning rate finder and 1-cycle policy are integrated, and it offers tools for model interpretation. It also supports deployment via standard formats like ONNX. Cursor v2's features revolve around code intelligence and automation. Its local-first agent can autonomously plan and execute tasks across multiple files. It has deep codebase search and semantic reasoning to understand project context, maintains full VS Code extension compatibility, and includes features for team collaboration, positioning it as a platform for software development, not model development.

sections.title: Use Cases
paragraphs: Use Fast.ai when your primary goal is to develop, train, and deploy machine learning models. It is ideal for: data scientists prototyping computer vision or NLP models quickly; educators teaching deep learning concepts; researchers applying transfer learning to new domains; and practitioners needing interpretable models for tabular data. Its strength is turning complex ML research into usable code. Use Cursor v2 when your primary goal is to write, refactor, understand, or maintain software applications. It is ideal for: software engineers refactoring large codebases; developers building features that span multiple files; teams onboarding new members to a complex project; and anyone wanting an AI pair programmer that can execute complex instructions. Its strength is understanding and manipulating code, not creating ML models.

sections.title: Pros & Cons
paragraphs: **Fast.ai Pros:** Radically simplifies deep learning with best-practice defaults; Excellent for education with a top-down, practical approach; Open-source and completely free; Provides SOTA results in vision, text, and tabular tasks with minimal code; Strong community and course support. **Fast.ai Cons:** Abstracts away lower-level PyTorch, which can be a limitation for advanced customization; Primarily focused on specific data types (vision, text, tabular); Users still need to manage data pipelines and compute infrastructure.

**Cursor v2 Pros:** Powerful autonomous agent can plan and execute complex coding tasks; Local-first architecture enhances privacy and speed; Deep integration with existing codebases via search and reasoning; Familiar VS Code interface lowers the learning curve; Freemium model allows testing before committing. **Cursor v2 Cons:** Advanced agentic features require a paid subscription; It does not help you build or train ML models itself; Can be overkill for simple editing tasks; Reliant on the underlying AI model's reasoning capabilities, which may have limitations.

verdict:
Choosing between Fast.ai and Cursor v2 in 2025 is not a matter of which tool is objectively better, but which problem you are trying to solve. They are complementary tools for different phases of the AI product lifecycle. For the machine learning practitioner, researcher, or student, Fast.ai is the unequivocal recommendation. Its value is unparalleled in lowering the barrier to entry for producing competitive deep learning models. By encapsulating years of best practices and research into a simple API, it allows you to focus on your data and problem domain rather than the intricacies of optimization loops and model architecture. It is a specialized power tool for a specific job: building AI models.

For the software engineer, full-stack developer, or tech lead managing a large codebase, Cursor v2 is the transformative tool. It reimagines the IDE as an active collaborator. If your work involves understanding legacy code, implementing features across multiple modules, or systematic refactoring, Cursor v2's agentic workflows can save immense amounts of time and reduce cognitive load. It is a general-purpose accelerator for the act of programming itself.

The final verdict is clear: **Use Fast.ai to build your AI models. Use Cursor v2 to build the application that uses and deploys those models.** They can, and often should, be used together in a workflow—Fast.ai for crafting the ML component within a Jupyter notebook or script, and Cursor v2 for integrating that model into a larger web service, API, or mobile application. Understanding this distinction is key to leveraging the right AI-powered tool for the right task in 2025's development ecosystem.

faqs.question: Can I use Fast.ai models within a project edited in Cursor v2?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. This is a highly complementary workflow. You would typically develop and train your machine learning model using Fast.ai in a Python environment (like a Jupyter notebook or script). Once the model is trained and exported (e.g., as a `.pkl` file or via ONNX), you can switch to Cursor v2 to work on the larger application codebase. Cursor v2 can help you write the API endpoints (e.g., using FastAPI or Flask), create the frontend interface, manage deployment scripts, and handle the integration logic that loads and serves your Fast.ai model. Cursor excels at this application development phase.

faqs.question: Does Cursor v2 help me train machine learning models like Fast.ai does?
faqs.answer: No, Cursor v2 does not function as a machine learning framework. It is an AI-powered code editor and autonomous development agent. While it can certainly help you write Python code that uses frameworks like Fast.ai, PyTorch, or TensorFlow—by generating boilerplate, suggesting imports, or debugging syntax—it does not provide the high-level APIs, pre-trained models, training loops, or data utilities that Fast.ai specializes in. Cursor v2 manipulates code; Fast.ai provides the specialized libraries and abstractions to execute machine learning tasks. For actual model training and experimentation, you would use Fast.ai directly within your development environment.
